Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls, sounding very upset, and asks if you have a moment to talk about a recent argument with their partner.
Expectation2: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation2: Steady rain and frequent lane changes from nearby cars raise the risk of sudden stops
Story: My phone buzzed just as I pulled away from the curb, windshield wipers fighting the steady rain. It was Sam, my closest friend, and I could hear the strain in his voice before he even finished saying hello. “Can you talk? I just had a huge fight with Jamie. I don’t know what to do.” I knew what he needed—someone to listen, to reassure him, to be present. But as I cradled the phone between my shoulder and ear, my eyes darted to the slick road ahead. Cars weaved unpredictably, brake lights flaring in the gray. As a taxi driver, I was supposed to keep both hands on the wheel, stay alert, and protect my passengers. But as a friend, I wanted to give Sam my full attention, to let him know he wasn’t alone. My heart pounded as I tried to split myself in two, torn between the urge to comfort him and the responsibility to drive safely. The rain hammered harder, and I felt the weight of both roles pressing in, demanding more than I could give at once.
